name: Enlargements with positive fractional scale factors

skills.name: Enlarge a shape, with a centre of enlargement given, by a positive fractional scale factor, where the centre of enlargement lies on the edge or outside of the object
Enlarge a shape, with a centre of enlargement given, by a positive fractional scale factor, where the centre of enlargement lies within the object
Describe an enlargement, with a centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor less than 1, where the centre of enlargement lies on the edge or outside of the object

explanations.A: After enlarging by scale factor 0.5, the point will be half the distance away from the centre of enlargement, so instead of 4 squares left and 2 down from the centre O, it will be 2 squares left and 1 square down.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have assumed that the origin is the centre of enlargement rather than the coordinate of 'O'.
explanations.C: Not quite, work out the distance from O to P and then multiply this distance by 0.5 (half the distance).
explanations.D: Not quite, I think you have enlarged by scale factor 2 as you are twice the distance from O. We are doing s.f 0.5 so half the distance away from O (the new point will actually be closer to the centre).

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you may have miscounted the length of the respective edges. The left hand edge of shape 1 is 3 squares long, and the corresponding length on shape 2 is 1 square long. The scale factor is the length of image divided by length of original.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have assumed that a negative scale factor will reduce the size of the image. Remember, the scale factor is the length of image divided by length of original.
explanations.C: Shape 1 is the image and shape 2 is the original shape. The left hand edge of shape 1 is 3 squares long, and the corresponding length on shape 2 is 1 square long. The scale factor is the length of image divided by length of original, which in this case is 1/3.
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you may have confused the image with the original. Shape 1 is the image and shape 2 is the original shape. The scale factor is the length of image divided by length of original.
